questions.text: A 23-year-old man came to the OPD with complaints of vomiting for which he was prescribed metoclopramide. What is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of metoclopramide is primarily D2 antagonism in the chemoreceptor trigger zone.

Metoclopramide has the following actions:

  • 5HT4 receptor agonism - prokinetic action
  • 5HT3 receptor antagonism - anti-emetic action at higher doses
  • Peripheral D2 antagonism - prokinetic action
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.text: Which of the following actions is exhibited by metoclopramide?

choices.text: Inhibits cholinergic smooth muscle stimulation in the gastrointestinal tract
Decreases the lower esophageal sphincter pressure

questions.solution:
Metoclopramide enhances gastrointestinal motility.

Acetylcholine increases gastrointestinal motility and lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone. Dopamine which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter suppresses ACh release. This decreases gastrointestinal motility and LES tone. Therefore, D2 receptor inhibition augments ACh release and enhances GI motility and LES tone. 

The action of metoclopramide is generally confined to the upper digestive tract and an increase in colonic motility is clinically insignificant.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the adverse effects characteristic of metoclopramide. The most common adverse effects of metoclopramide involve the central nervous system because it crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blocks the central D2 receptors.

The adverse effects include:

  • Restlessness
  • Drowsiness
  • Insomnia
  • Anxiety
  • Agitation 
  • Extrapyramidal effects - acute reaction with high doses and long-term therapy. (due to central dopamine receptor blockade)
    • Dystonias
    • Akathisia
    • Parkinsonian features
    • Tardive dyskinesia 

Adverse events are more common among the elderly. Long-term use should be avoided unless absolutely necessary.

questions.text: A patient developed abnormal posturing and grimacing following the administration of metoclopramide. Which drug will you administer to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of dystonia associated with D2 blocker (metoclopramide) use. Promethazine is the drug of choice.

It is a first-generation antihistaminic having significant central anticholinergic activity.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is implicated in prolonging QT interval and causing serious arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
Cisapride is associated with prolongation of QT interval and causation of serious ventricular arrhythmias.

Prolongation of QT interval is due to blockade of rapid delayed rectifier potassium channels. It is banned or has restricted use in most of the countries.

Ondansetron is associated with asymptomatic electrocardiogram changes, including prolongation of PT and QTc intervals.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs do not act as a prokinetic agent by 5HT4 agonism?
questions.solution:
Domperidone does not have any 5HT4 agonist action. It mainly acts by D2 antagonist action.

5HT4 agonism and D2 antagonism can result in prokinetic action by increasing the cholinergic activity of the gut.

The 5HT4 agonist action is shown by:

  • Metoclopramide 
  • Cisapride
  • Mosapride
  • Itopride
  • Renzapride

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic?
questions.solution:
Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic agent. Its derivative (Bisacodyl) is used as a laxative.

Prokinetic agents are the drugs that increase GI motility and transit of material in the GI tract. These agents include:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonists- metoclopramide and domperidone
  • Serotonin receptor agonists- cisapride and prucalopride
  • Motilin
  • Macrolide antibiotics mimicking motilin - erythromycin
  • Miscellaneous agents:
    • Sincalide (C-terminal octapeptide of CCK)
    • Camicinal (motilin receptor agonist)
    • Relamorelin (ghrelin receptor agonist)
    • Velusetrag and naronapride (5HT4 agonists)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with unhealthy eating practices now complains of constipation. He took bisacodyl, following which he had symptomatic relief. Which group of drugs does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Bisacodyl is a stimulant laxative.

Stimulant laxatives act by irritation of the intestinal mucosa and direct action on myenteric plexus neurons stimulating motility and secretion.

Examples of stimulant/irritant laxatives are:

  • Bisacodyl
  • Sodium picosulfate
  • Anthraquinones like senna, cascara sagrada
  • Castor oil

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. He admitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a brownish moiré pattern that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coli.

Bisacodyl is also implicated in causing melanosis coli.

questions.text: You want to prescribe a bulk-forming laxative to an elderly patient with constipation. Which among the following would you not prescribe?
questions.solution:
Liquid paraffin is not a bulk-forming laxative. It is a mineral oil and acts as a stool softener.

It is rarely used in clinical practice today because of its drawbacks, such as: 

  • Bland and unpleasant taste
  • Risk of lipoid pneumonia
  • Anal leakage

Bulk-forming laxatives are:

  • Bran
  • Psyllium
  • Methylcellulose
  • Polycarbophil

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD by his mother with complaints of acute watery diarrhea for 2 days.  Oral rehydration solution, zinc supplement, and a peripheral enkephalinase inhibitor were prescribed. Which of the following drugs did he prescribe?
questions.solution:
Racecadotril is a peripheral enkephalinase inhibitor.

Enkephalins are endogenous delta-opioid receptor agonists that decrease intestinal secretions without affecting motility. Enkephalinase is the enzyme that degrades enkephalin.

Racecadotril, by inhibiting the enkephalinase enzyme increases enkephalin level and acts as an antisecretory agent in diarrhea. It has minimal/no effect on motility. Racecadotril is indicated for symptomatic treatment of diarrhea in infants and children.

Options B and C: Diphenoxylate and loperamide are μ-opioid receptor agonists.

Option D: Linaclotide is a guanylate cyclase agonist.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who is on anti-retroviral therapy presents with complaints of diarrhea for three days. An infectious etiology is ruled out on work-up. Which of the following drugs is preferred to manage his diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This is a case of non-infectious diarrhea associated with antiretroviral therapy (ART).Â Crofelemer is indicated for non-infectious diarrhea associated with ART in HIV/AIDS.

Crofelemer has minimal systemic absorption. It acts by inhibiting the cyclic AMP-stimulated CFTR chloride channel and calcium-activated chloride channels on the luminal side of the intestine.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman complains of recurrent episodes of constipation and crampy abdominal pain for the last 4 months. The pain is relieved on defecation. After investigations, a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is considered. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The drug used in irritable bowel syndrome with constipation is lubiprostone.

It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating Cl-channels in the intestine and increasing fluid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time.

Eluxadoline is an FDA-approved opioid drug for the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS in adults.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: The use of which of the following drugs is associated with ischemic colitis?
questions.solution:
Ischemic colitis is associated with the use of alosetron. It is a 5HT3 antagonist that may suppress intestinal relaxation leading to ischemic colitis in susceptible individuals.

It is approved for resistant diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome in female patients.

It is either withdrawn/ has restricted use because of the serious side effect.

questions.text: A patient who is suffering from chronic constipation is prescribed a guanylcycline C agonist. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The guanylcycline-C (GC-C) agonist indicated in chronic constipation is linaclotide.

Linaclotide is a peptide agonist that activates GC-C which leads to increased synthesis of cyclic-GMP. This results in enhanced chloride and bicarbonate secretion into the intestinal lumen leading to increased water secretion and enhanced motility.

It is indicated in constipation-predominant IBS in females and in chronic idiopathic constipation in adults.

questions.text: Prucalopride is a ______.
questions.solution:
Prucalopride is a specific 5HT4 receptor agonist which increases bowel movements.

It is approved for use in women with chronic constipation where other laxatives have failed to provide relief.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman suffering from erratic bowel habits for the past few months is diagnosed with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. Which antibiotic is specifically approved for the treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
The antibiotic that is specifically approved for diarrhea-predominant IBS is rifaximin. It is an RNA synthesis inhibitor.  It may provide benefit by altering the gastrointestinal flora favorably.

Rifabutin, rifampicin and rifapentine are antitubercular agents.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primiparous woman came to the OPD with complaints of nausea and vomiting at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is specifically indicated to provide symptomatic relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
Doxylamine is indicated with pyridoxine to reduce mild to moderate nausea and vomiting in the early stages of pregnancy.

It is a histamine H1 antagonist and its efficacy is improved when combined with pyridoxine.

Combinations of domperidone, dolasetron and metoclopramide with pyridoxine are not specifically indicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice in a patient complaining of nausea and vomiting, 2 days after commencement of a cisplatin-based chemotherapeutic regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from delayed emesis associated with cancer chemotherapy.

Combined therapy with aprepitant (NK-1/ neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist), a 5-HT3-receptor antagonist, and dexamethasone is the best treatment in delayed emesis associated with cancer chemotherapy.

Delayed chemotherapy-induced vomiting is any emesis occurring >24 hours after chemotherapy. If NK-1 receptor antagonists are not used in the combination, delayed emesis is prevented only in 30% of the patients. Usage of 5HT3 antagonists alone has no role in the treatment of delayed emesis.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presents with anorexia and weight loss. Which of the following is a naturally extracted cannabinoid that is approved for his condition?
questions.solution:
Dronabinol or delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol is a cannabinoid that can be extracted naturally.

It is the only cannabinoid that is approved for anorexia and weight loss associated with AIDS. It is obtained from the marijuana plant or can be synthesized chemically.

Option B: Nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid. 

Dronabinol and nabilone are approved for the treatment of refractory cases of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Option C: Tibolone is a 19-norsteroid derivative specifically to be used for hormone replacement therapy.

Option D: Cannabidiol is a cannabinoid approved for the treatment of seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, Dravet syndrome, or tuberous sclerosis complex.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about aprepitant is false?

choices.text: Ameliorate nausea and vomiting induced by chemotherapy

questions.solution:
Aprepitant is a high-affinity NK1 receptor antagonist that blocks the emetic action of substance P.

Aprepitant is well absorbed orally and crosses the blood-brain barrier.

Co-administration of oral aprepitant with dexamethasone and ondansetron significantly enhances the antiemetic efficacy against the highly emetogenic side effects of chemotherapeutic drugs like cisplatin and cyclophosphamide.

It is metabolized in the liver by the CYP450 enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following antiemetic drugs also decreases acid secretion due to its action on H1 receptors?
questions.solution:
An antiemetic drug that also decreases acid secretion due to its action on H1 histamine receptors is promethazine. 

The central anticholinergic activity of promethazine is responsible for antiemetic action.

questions.text: The 5HT3 antagonist having maximum potency in chemotherapy-induced vomiting is:
questions.solution:
The 5HT3 antagonist having maximum potency in chemotherapy-induced vomiting is palonosetron.

It has a high affinity for 5HT3 and is also the longest-acting 5HT3 antagonist. This makes it more effective in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy.

During chemotherapy, there is cell lysis and 5HT (serotonin) is released from the gut mucosa. The released serotonin acts on the 5HT3 receptors, activating the vagal afferents in the gut that carry the emetogenic impulses to the nucleus tractus solitarius and chemoreceptor trigger zone. The selective blockade of 5HT3 receptors reduces the emetogenic impulses.

Granisetron, dolasetron, and ondansetron are also effective for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

Cilansetron is a new 5HT3 antagonist indicated for irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea.

questions.text: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is_________.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is granisetron.

Granisetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist. They are the most effective drugs for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced and post-operative nausea and vomiting.

Palonosetron is a second-generation 5HT3 antagonist that has the highest affinity for 5HT3 receptors and has the maximum potency. It is also the longest acting that makes it effective in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy. Palonosetron has minimal/no propensity to cause QT interval prolongation.

questions.text: QT interval prolongation is minimal with which of the following 5-HT3 antagonists?
questions.solution:
Palonosetron is a second-generation 5-HT3 antagonist and has minimal/no propensity to cause QT prolongation.

First-generation 5-HT3 antagonists have an increased risk of QT interval prolongation.

Intravenous dolasetron is contraindicated for prophylaxis of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting for the same reason.

questions.text: Which of the following NK1 receptor antagonists has the longest half-life?
questions.solution: Rolapitant has the longest plasma half-life of 180 hours. It is a highly selective NK1 receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He is afebrile and has mild dehydration. What should be the treatment?
questions.solution:
It is a case of acute diarrhea in an afebrile, stable patient which can be managed with ORS alone.

Management of diarrhea:

  • Mild-moderate dehydration - ORS.
  • Severe dehydration- IV fluids are given.
  • Afebrile patient - No antibiotics are given.
  • Febrile patient - empirical antibiotics. If only bacterial etiology is suspected, ciprofloxacin is given. If giardiasis is suspected, metronidazole or tinidazole are recommended.

National ORS Day is celebrated every year on 29th July to highlight the importance of Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS) as a cost-effective method of health intervention to prevent death due to dehydration in acute diarrhoeal diseases. ADD accounts for one of the leading causes of mortality in infants and young children in many developing countries.

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: You and your friend plan for a mountain trip for the day after. What medication would you advise him to help with his motion sickness?

choices.text: Ranitidine tablet before start of trip
Scopolamine patch the night before trip
Omeprazole the night before and before start of trip

questions.solution:
In the above case, a scopolamine patch the night before the trip should be advised.

Treatment for motion sickness :

  • Scopolamine patch- preferred, most effective.
    • Do not give to children <10 years of age.
    • Place patch behind the ears at least 4 hours before travel and replace every 72 hours as needed.
    • Transdermal patch – Most effective
    • Oral dose - 0.4–0.6 mg one hour before travel and then TID may be recommended.
  • Cinnarizine – 30mg, 2 hours prior to travel, and 15mg TID as required. Not as effective as scopolamine. Moderately effective.
  • Promethazine
  • Other drugs (minimally effective): 
    • Cyclizine
    • Dimenhydrinate
    • Diphenhydramine
    • Meclizine

PPI’s / ranitidine / traditional ginger – all are ineffective.
